title: Show when an update is available and enable users to auto-update
description:
Show users when an abacus update is available and help them upgrade.

## Problem Statement
Users have no way to know when a new version of abacus is available. They must manually check GitHub releases or remember to run `brew upgrade`. This leads to users running outdated versions and missing bug fixes, new features, and security updates.

## Solution
Add an update notification system that:
1. Checks GitHub releases API at startup (async, non-blocking)
2. Shows a toast notification when an update is available
3. For Homebrew users: shows `brew upgrade abacus` instructions
4. For direct download users: offers one-key auto-update via [U] hotkey

## Design Document
See: docs/plans/2025-12-25-update-notification-design.md

## Key Design Decisions
- **Startup only**: Check once at launch, don't poll during use
- **Non-blocking**: Async check doesn't slow down app startup
- **Respect package managers**: Homebrew users get instructions, not auto-update (avoids desyncing brew's package tracking)
- **Graceful failures**: Network errors silently ignored, update failures show manual instructions
- **10 second toast**: Long enough to read and act, short enough to not annoy
- **Skip for dev builds**: Version="dev" skips update check entirely

## User Experience
Homebrew user sees:
```
 ‚¨Ü Update available: v0.6.2
   Run: brew upgrade abacus     [10s]
```

Direct download user sees:
```
 ‚¨Ü Update available: v0.6.2
   Press [U] to update           [10s]
```

## Implementation Components
1. internal/update/checker.go - Version checker (GitHub API)
2. internal/update/updater.go - Auto-updater (download + atomic replace)
3. internal/ui/view_toasts.go - Update toast UI
4. cmd/abacus/main.go - Startup integration
5. internal/config/config.go - Skip flag configuration

title: Implement auto-updater (download + atomic replace)
description:
Implement the auto-updater that downloads and installs new versions.

## Update Flow

1. **Determine asset URL**: Match runtime.GOOS and runtime.GOARCH to find correct tarball
   - darwin/arm64 ‚Üí abacus_X.Y.Z_darwin_arm64.tar.gz
   - darwin/amd64 ‚Üí abacus_X.Y.Z_darwin_amd64.tar.gz
   - linux/amd64 ‚Üí abacus_X.Y.Z_linux_amd64.tar.gz
   - etc.

2. **Download to temp file**: Download tarball to os.TempDir()

3. **Extract binary**: Untar to get the abacus binary

4. **Verify checksum** (optional): Download checksums.txt and verify SHA256

5. **Atomic replace**:
   ```go
   exe, _ := os.Executable()
   os.Rename(exe, exe + ".old")      // Backup current
   os.Rename(newBinary, exe)         // Install new
   os.Chmod(exe, 0755)               // Ensure executable
   os.Remove(exe + ".old")           // Clean up backup
   ```

6. **Return result**: Success message or error

## Error Handling
- Permission denied ‚Üí return clear error, caller shows manual instructions
- Download failed ‚Üí clean up temp files, return error
- Checksum mismatch ‚Üí delete download, return error
- Any failure ‚Üí graceful fallback to manual instructions

## Platform Considerations
- Windows: Cannot replace running executable; may need different strategy
- For v1: Show manual instructions on Windows instead of auto-update

## Security
- HTTPS only for downloads
- Verify checksums when available
- Don't execute downloaded code, just replace binary

title: Tree title truncation: Replace word wrap with ellipsis when columns enabled
description:
Modify tree title rendering to use truncation with ellipsis instead of word wrapping when columns are enabled. This ensures single-line rows for proper column alignment.

## Current Behavior
Titles wrap to multiple lines using `wrapWithHangingIndent()`:
```
  ‚ñº ‚óã ab-xyz  This is a very long title that
              wraps to the next line
```

## New Behavior (when columns enabled)
Titles truncate with ellipsis:
```
  ‚ñº ‚óã ab-xyz  This is a very long tit...  ‚îÇ 2h ago ‚îÇ
```

## Implementation Details
- Modify `buildTreeLines()` in `internal/ui/tree.go`
- Check `config.GetBool(KeyTreeShowColumns)` to decide behavior
- If columns enabled: truncate title to fit available space, append '...'
- If columns disabled: use existing word wrap behavior
- Minimum tree width: 40 characters (including indent, icon, ID)

## Truncation Logic
```go
func truncateTitle(title string, maxWidth int) string {
    if lipgloss.Width(title) <= maxWidth {
        return title
    }
    // Account for '...' suffix (3 chars)
    for i := len(title) - 1; i >= 0; i-- {
        candidate := title[:i] + "..."
        if lipgloss.Width(candidate) <= maxWidth {
            return candidate
        }
    }
    return "..."
}
```

## Edge Cases
- Very narrow terminals: ensure at least ID + '...' fits
- Unicode titles: use lipgloss.Width() for accurate measurement
- Empty titles: render nothing (no '...')

## Backward Compatibility
- Detail pane still shows full title with wrapping
- Other views (search results, etc.) unaffected
- Only tree view changes, and only when columns enabled

title: Responsive column hiding: Hide columns R‚ÜíL when terminal is narrow
description:
Implement responsive behavior that progressively hides columns from right to left as the terminal width decreases, ensuring the tree remains usable.

## Responsive Behavior Stages

| Terminal Width | Behavior |
|----------------|----------|
| Wide | Full tree titles + all columns |
| Medium | Truncated tree titles (min 40ch) + all columns |
| Narrow | Tree at min width + hide rightmost column (comments) |
| Very narrow | Tree at min width + hide all columns |

## Width Calculation Logic
```go
const minTreeWidth = 40

func calculateVisibleColumns(totalWidth int, columns []TreeColumn) []TreeColumn {
    available := totalWidth - minTreeWidth
    if available <= 0 {
        return nil // no space for columns
    }
    
    var visible []TreeColumn
    usedWidth := 0
    for _, col := range columns {
        if usedWidth + col.Width + 1 <= available { // +1 for separator space
            visible = append(visible, col)
            usedWidth += col.Width + 1
        } else {
            break // can't fit more columns
        }
    }
    return visible
}
```

## Column Priority (left = higher priority)
1. lastUpdated - shows staleness, important for triage
2. comments - shows discussion activity, nice-to-have

When space is tight, comments hides first because:
- Time is more critical for identifying stale issues
- Binary nature of 'has comments' vs continuous nature of time

## Edge Cases
- Terminal resized during session: recalculate on each render
- Detail pane toggle: recalculate when ShowDetails changes
- Very narrow (< 40 chars): hide all columns, show tree only

## No Hidden Indicator (Design Decision)
We decided against showing an indicator when columns are hidden because:
- Users will notice columns are missing
- Adds visual noise
- Can revisit if users request it

## Testing
- Test with various terminal widths
- Test with detail pane open/closed
- Verify smooth transition as width changes
- Ensure tree never goes below minimum width

title: Handle relates-to dependency type in builder
description:
Update the graph builder to handle the new `relates-to` dependency type alongside the existing `related` type.

## Background

Beads has two similar but distinct dependency types:
- `related` (legacy): One-way, created via `bd dep add X Y --type related`
- `relates-to` (new): Bidirectional, created via `bd relate X Y`

The `bd relate` command creates TWO dependency records (X‚ÜíY and Y‚ÜíX), both with type `relates-to`. Currently abacus only handles `related`, so issues linked via `bd relate` don't appear in the "See Also" section.

## Implementation

In internal/graph/builder.go, update the switch case:

```go
case "related", "relates-to":
    if related, ok := nodeMap[dep.TargetID]; ok {
        // Dedup check: relates-to stores both directions, avoid double-linking
        alreadyLinked := false
        for _, r := range node.Related {
            if r.Issue.ID == related.Issue.ID {
                alreadyLinked = true
                break
            }
        }
        if !alreadyLinked {
            node.Related = append(node.Related, related)
            related.Related = append(related.Related, node)
        }
    }
```

## Why Dedup Check?

- For `related`: We add both directions manually (existing behavior)
- For `relates-to`: Both directions already exist in storage, so without dedup we'd add each link twice

The dedup check makes the code work correctly for both old and new dependency types.

## Backward Compatibility

This is purely additive - we're adding a new case to the switch. Old databases without `relates-to` dependencies work unchanged.

title: Detail pane title wrapping is completely broken - bead ID wraps and indentation fails
description:
The detail pane title wrapping is CRITICALLY broken. The bead ID itself is wrapping, indentation is wrong, and blank lines appear. This makes the UI unusable at ALL widths.

**SCREENSHOTS DOCUMENTING THE BUG:**
- `/Users/chrisedwards/Desktop/Screenshot 2025-11-22 at 2.51.58 PM.png` (Wide - ALSO BROKEN!)
- `/Users/chrisedwards/Desktop/Screenshot 2025-11-22 at 2.51.46 PM.png` (Medium - BROKEN, ID wraps)
- `/Users/chrisedwards/Desktop/Screenshot 2025-11-22 at 2.51.31 PM.png` (Narrow - CATASTROPHIC, blank lines)

## Critical Issues Observed:

### Screenshot 1 (Widest - ALSO BROKEN):
```
ab-176  Add incremental background refresh for real-
time updates
```
‚ùå **WRONG**: "time updates" wraps back to column 0, directly under "ab-176"

**Should be:**
```
ab-176  Add incremental background refresh for real-
        time updates
```
The wrapped line must be indented to align with "Add" (start of title), NOT with "ab-" (start of ID).

### Screenshot 2 (Medium width - CRITICALLY BROKEN):
```
ab-
176  Add incremental background refresh for real-
     time updates
```
‚ùå **MAJOR BUG**: The bead ID "ab-176" is being SPLIT across lines:
- Line 1: "ab-"
- Line 2: "176  Add incremental background refresh for real-"
- Line 3: "     time updates"

**The bead ID should NEVER wrap under any circumstances!**

### Screenshot 3 (Narrowest - CATASTROPHICALLY BROKEN):
```
ab-176  Add incremental background refresh for real-

time
        updates
```
‚ùå **MULTIPLE CRITICAL BUGS**:
1. Blank line appears after "real-"
2. "time" on its own line with NO indentation (should be indented)
3. "updates" appears with wrong indentation
4. Word breaking is completely broken

## Root Cause Analysis:

The wrapping algorithm is treating the ENTIRE string "ab-176  Add incremental..." as wrappable text WITHOUT any hanging indent. It's applying simple word wrapping that doesn't respect the ID as a non-wrapping prefix.

The code is likely doing:
```go
// WRONG - wraps everything including ID, no indent
wrapped := wordWrap("ab-176  Add incremental background...", width)
```

It should be doing:
```go
// RIGHT - ID is prefix, title wraps with hanging indent
id := "ab-176"
separator := "  "
title := "Add incremental background refresh for real-time updates"
prefix := id + separator
wrapped := wrapWithPrefix(title, width, prefix, hangingIndent=len(prefix))
```

## Overview

## File: internal/ui/sort.go

### Current Sort Order (from comments)
sortSubtasks: Status-first (in_progress -> ready -> blocked -> closed)

### Updated Sort Order
in_progress -> ready -> blocked -> deferred -> closed

Or potentially:
in_progress -> ready -> blocked/deferred (grouped) -> closed

### Rationale
- in_progress: Active work, always first
- ready: Can be started, high visibility
- blocked: Waiting on something, show what's stuck
- deferred: Intentionally postponed, lower priority than blocked
- closed: Done, at the bottom

### nodeStatusCategory() Function
This function assigns a numeric category for sorting. Update to handle new statuses:

```go
func nodeStatusCategory(n *graph.Node) int {
    switch n.Issue.Status {
    case "in_progress":
        return 0
    case "open":
        if n.IsBlocked {
            return 2 // blocked by dependencies
        }
        return 1 // ready
    case "blocked":
        return 2 // explicit blocked status
    case "deferred":
        return 3 // on ice - after blocked
    case "closed":
        return 4
    default:
        return 5
    }
}
```

- Deferred issues sort after blocked issues
- Blocked issues (both explicit and dependency) sort together
- Sort order is visually logical in tree view

**Ctrl+Enter Behavior (Section 4.3):**

| Field | On Ctrl+Enter | Rationale |
|-------|---------------|-----------|

case tea.KeyCtrlEnter:

        m.flashTitleError()
        return m, nil
    }

func (m *CreateOverlay) prepareForNextEntry() tea.Cmd {

}

title: Replace overlayBottomRight() with lipgloss.Place()
description: The 60-line manual overlay positioning function `overlayBottomRight()` in app.go:759-818 can be replaced with lipgloss's built-in `lipgloss.Place(width, height, lipgloss.Right, lipgloss.Bottom, overlay)`. This is a quick win with low risk and high reward - approximately 55 lines saved.
notes:
**Research findings (2024-11-28):**

The original premise was incorrect - `lipgloss.Place()` in v1.x positions content in whitespace, it does NOT overlay on existing rendered content.

**What overlayBottomRight() does:**
- True compositing: merges overlay ON TOP of already-rendered background
- Preserves background where overlay doesn't cover
- ANSI-aware string manipulation using `ansi.Cut` and `ansi.Truncate`

**Solution identified:**
Lipgloss v2.0.0-beta.3 (released July 2024) introduces a Canvas/Layer compositing API:
```go
canvas := lipgloss.NewCanvas(
    backgroundLayer.X(0).Y(0),
    toastLayer.X(x).Y(y).Z(1),  // higher Z = on top
)
return canvas.Render()
```

**Decision:** Wait for lipgloss v2.0 stable release before implementing. Keep current `overlayBottomRight()` implementation until then.

## Overview
Update the view mode filtering logic to exclude issues with blocked or deferred status from both Active and Ready views.

## Files to Update

### internal/ui/state_filter.go
Both ViewModeActive and ViewModeReady filters should exclude blocked and deferred statuses.

Current Active logic (line 50-52):
```go
case ViewModeActive:
    // Show non-closed issues
    return domainIssue.Status() != domain.StatusClosed
```

Current Ready logic (line 54-55):
```go
case ViewModeReady:
    // Show ready issues (open + not blocked)
    return domainIssue.IsReady()
```

Both need to also check for status != blocked and status != deferred.

### internal/ui/app.go
Review nodeStatusCategory() and any other places that determine if an issue is ready or active.

## Filtering Logic

### Active View
An issue shows in Active view if:
- status is NOT closed
- status is NOT deferred (deferred = on ice, not active work)
- status is NOT blocked (manually blocked, not active work)
- status is NOT tombstone

### Ready View  
An issue is ready if ALL of these are true:
1. status == open (not in_progress, not blocked, not deferred, not closed)
2. Not blocked by dependencies (node.IsBlocked == false)

Note: in_progress issues may show in ready view depending on context, but blocked/deferred should NEVER show.

## Beads Reference
From beads ready.go GetReadyWork():
```go
if filter.Status == "" {
    whereClauses = append(whereClauses, "i.status IN ('open', 'in_progress')")
}
```

Beads includes in_progress in ready work by default but excludes blocked/deferred.

## Acceptance Criteria
- ViewModeActive excludes issues with status=blocked
- ViewModeActive excludes issues with status=deferred
- ViewModeReady excludes issues with status=blocked
- ViewModeReady excludes issues with status=deferred
- ViewModeReady still shows open issues that are not dependency-blocked
- Statistics correctly count blocked/deferred separately from open

```

## Key Responsibilities
1. Calculate available width for tree vs columns
2. Render columns with fixed widths at consistent X positions
3. Extend selection/cross-highlight background across columns
4. Handle theme colors for column content

## Width Calculation
```go
totalWidth := m.width - margins
if m.ShowDetails {
    totalWidth -= m.viewport.Width
}

columnWidth := calculateColumnWidths() // sum of enabled columns
treeWidth := totalWidth - columnWidth
if treeWidth < minTreeWidth {

    // columns will be hidden in responsive phase
}
```

```go

    Key       string // config key suffix
    Width     int    // fixed width in chars
    Render    func(node *graph.Node) string
    Alignment lipgloss.Position // Right
}

    {Key: "comments", Width: 5, Render: renderCommentsColumn, Alignment: lipgloss.Right},
}

1. Build tree content (truncated title)
2. Pad tree content to treeWidth
3. For each enabled column:

   - Append to row
4. Apply selection background to full row

Currently `buildSelectedRow()` renders with `Width(treeWidth)`. Must update to `Width(totalWidth)` and render columns within the styled block.

title: Time formatting helper: Implement Stripe-inspired relative/absolute time display
description:
Create a time formatting function that produces human-friendly, compact time strings following the Stripe-inspired design.

## Format Specification

| Age | Output | Example |
|-----|--------|---------|
| < 1 minute | `now` | 30 seconds ago ‚Üí `now` |
| 1-59 minutes | `Nm ago` | 5 minutes ago ‚Üí `5m ago` |
| 1-23 hours | `Nh ago` | 3 hours ago ‚Üí `3h ago` |
| 1-6 days | `Nd ago` | 2 days ago ‚Üí `2d ago` |
| 7+ days (same year) | `Mon D` | Dec 10 |
| Different year | `Mon 'YY` | `Dec '23` |

## Function Signature
```go
// FormatRelativeTime formats a timestamp for display in tree columns.
// Returns a compact, human-friendly string (max ~8 chars).
func FormatRelativeTime(t time.Time) string
```

## Implementation Location
Create new file: `internal/ui/timeformat.go` (or add to existing helpers)

## Implementation Notes
```go
func FormatRelativeTime(t time.Time) string {
    now := time.Now()
    diff := now.Sub(t)
    
    switch {
    case diff < time.Minute:
        return "now"
    case diff < time.Hour:
        return fmt.Sprintf("%dm ago", int(diff.Minutes()))
    case diff < 24*time.Hour:
        return fmt.Sprintf("%dh ago", int(diff.Hours()))
    case diff < 7*24*time.Hour:
        return fmt.Sprintf("%dd ago", int(diff.Hours()/24))
    default:
        if t.Year() == now.Year() {
            return t.Format("Jan 2")
        }
        return t.Format("Jan '06")
    }
}
```

## Edge Cases
- Future timestamps: show absolute date (shouldn't happen, but defensive)
- Invalid/zero timestamps: return empty string
- Timezone handling: use local timezone for 'same day' calculations

## Testing
Test cases for each threshold boundary:
- 59 seconds ‚Üí 'now'
- 61 seconds ‚Üí '1m ago'
- 59 minutes ‚Üí '59m ago'
- 61 minutes ‚Üí '1h ago'
- 23 hours ‚Üí '23h ago'
- 25 hours ‚Üí '1d ago'
- 6 days ‚Üí '6d ago'
- 8 days (same year) ‚Üí 'Dec 16'
- Different year ‚Üí 'Dec '23'

## Why This Matters
The time format is a key UX element. Getting the thresholds and formatting right makes the difference between 'usable' and 'delightful'.

title: Implement hierarchical child sorting with cascading status and date prioritization
description:
Currently, nodes in the tree view (both root-level parents and children within parents) don't follow a consistent, priority-based ordering. This makes it difficult to identify the most important work.

**Current behavior:**
- Beads are displayed in an undefined or insertion order
- No visual prioritization of active work
- Hard to see which branches have in-progress or ready work
- No FIFO ordering to highlight work that's been waiting longest

**Desired behavior:**
Implement cascading sort order for ALL nodes (root parents and children at every level), where parents are sorted based on the aggregated status and dates of their entire subtree.

**Primary Sort Criteria (by status, cascading to descendants):**
1. **In-progress**: Node has in-progress status OR any of its descendants are in-progress
2. **Ready**: Node is ready OR any of its descendants are ready (no blockers)
3. **Open**: Node is open OR any of its descendants are open
4. **Closed**: Node is closed AND all descendants are closed

**Secondary Sort (within same status group, chronological - oldest first):**
- **In Progress**: By oldest date set to in-progress (of node or any descendant) - items in-progress longest appear first
- **Ready**: By oldest create date (of node or any descendant) - oldest ready work first (FIFO)
- **Open**: By oldest create date (of node or any descendant) - oldest open work first (FIFO)
- **Closed**: By oldest closed date (of node or any descendant) - chronological completion history

Note: "oldest" means earliest date (e.g., created last week comes before created yesterday)

**Cascading Logic:**
When determining a node's effective status and date for sorting:
- Walk the entire subtree beneath each node
- If ANY descendant has in-progress status, the node sorts in the in-progress group
- Use the oldest relevant date across the entire subtree for that status
- This ensures active work bubbles up AND work that's been waiting longest is highlighted

**Scope:**
- Apply this sorting to root-level parent nodes (based on their entire subtree)
- Apply this sorting to children within every parent node (based on their subtrees)
- Parents and children all use the same cascading logic
- Maintain sort order through tree expansion/collapse operations
- Re-sort when data refreshes (status changes, new beads added)

# Extended Status Support for Abacus

## Overview
Beads has evolved to include additional status values beyond the original open/in_progress/closed trinity. Abacus currently only supports these three statuses, which causes issues when viewing beads databases that use the extended statuses.

This epic tracks the work to add proper support for:
- **blocked** - Manual blocking (distinct from dependency-calculated blocking)
- **deferred** - Deliberately postponed (on ice) issues
- **tombstone** - Soft-deleted issues (internal handling only)

Note: pinned status is deliberately excluded from this scope as it is designed for multi-agent workflows and does not have a clear use case in single-user TUI context.

## Problem Statement
When abacus encounters issues with status values like blocked or deferred, it either:
1. Fails validation in the domain layer
2. Displays them incorrectly (wrong icon, wrong color, wrong filtering)
3. Prevents users from setting these statuses via the UI

This creates friction for users who use both bd CLI and abacus TUI.

## Solution Approach
Add first-class support for blocked and deferred statuses with appropriate icons, colors, filtering, and transitions.

### blocked Status
- Icon: (blocked) - same as dependency-blocked
- Color: Red (#f26d78)
- Meaning: User manually marked this as blocked

### deferred Status
- Icon: (snowflake) - conveys on ice
- Color: Cool blue/gray
- Meaning: Deliberately postponed for later

### tombstone Status
- Internal only - filter out from all views
- No UI representation needed

## Success Criteria
1. Issues with blocked/deferred status display correctly
2. Users can change status via overlay
3. Ready filter excludes blocked and deferred
4. All tests pass

title: Slack-style submit for multiline text fields
description:
## Problem

Ctrl+Enter is broken in Ghostty terminal. Ghostty uses the Kitty keyboard protocol which sends `CSI 13;5u` for Ctrl+Enter, but bubbletea v1.x doesn't recognize this sequence. The current code checks `msg.String() == "ctrl+enter"` which never matches in Ghostty.

This particularly affects the **CommentOverlay** which only has a multiline textarea - users cannot submit comments in Ghostty because:
- Enter inserts newlines (expected textarea behavior)
- Ctrl+S doesn't work reliably
- There's no other field to Tab to

## Solution

Adopt Slack/Discord-style keybindings for multiline text fields:

| Key | Action |
|-----|--------|
| Enter | Submit the form |
| Shift+Enter | Insert newline |

This pattern is widely understood and works reliably across all terminals (Ghostty, iTerm2, etc).

## Design Document

See: `docs/plans/2025-12-25-slack-style-multiline-submit.md`

## Scope

**Affected components:**
1. `overlay_comment.go` - CommentOverlay textarea
2. `overlay_create.go` - Description field only

**Also removing:**
- Ctrl+Enter bulk create mode (rarely used, broken in Ghostty)

## Key Decisions

1. **Why not upgrade bubbletea to v2?** - v2 is still in RC, would require broader changes, and this fix is simpler
2. **Why not add kitty protocol detection manually?** - Hacky, would need maintenance
3. **Why remove bulk mode?** - Rarely used per user feedback, and finding a reliable alternative key is complex
4. **Why Slack model?** - Widely understood UX pattern, works everywhere

Achieve <50ms perceived latency by injecting new nodes directly.

**Spec Reference:** docs/CREATE_BEAD_SPEC.md Section 2.6 (Perceived Instantaneity), Section 12 (Manual Tree Injection)

**Goal (Section 10):** Perceived latency < 50ms

**Current Flow:**
1. User presses Enter
2. Run `bd create`
3. Wait for full tree refresh
4. Find and highlight new node
5. ~500ms+ latency

**New Flow (Section 12):**
1. User presses Enter
2. Run `bd create --json ...` (returns full JSON)
3. Parse JSON response to get **actual stored data**
4. **Do NOT** call full tree refresh
5. Construct node from returned JSON (not from input data!)
6. Insert into parent's children, re-sort
7. Set cursor to new node
8. Return immediately (~50ms)
9. Background: trigger tree refresh (eventually consistent)

**Why use --json response (Section 12):**
- Returns exact data stored in database
- Handles server-side defaults/transformations
- Guarantees displayed node matches actual bead
- Avoids sync issues

**Implementation:**
```go
func (m *App) insertNodeFromCreate(parentID string, issue beads.FullIssue) {
    newNode := &graph.Node{
        Issue: beads.LiteIssue{
            ID:        issue.ID,
            Title:     issue.Title,
            Status:    issue.Status,
            Priority:  issue.Priority,
            IssueType: issue.IssueType,
            Labels:    issue.Labels,
        },
        Children: []*graph.Node{},
    }
    
    if parentID == "" {
        // Root insertion
        m.roots = append(m.roots, newNode)
        sortNodes(m.roots)
    } else {
        // Find parent and insert
        parent := m.findNodeByID(parentID)
        if parent != nil {
            parent.Children = append(parent.Children, newNode)
            sortNodes(parent.Children)
        }
    }
    
    m.recalcVisibleRows()
    m.moveCursorToNode(issue.ID)
}
```

title: Establish outerWidth/innerWidth box model for UI components
description:
## Problem

UI components leak box model implementation details. Callers must know about lipgloss quirks (border renders outside Width()) and manually subtract magic numbers (-2, -4) when sizing components. This leads to:

- Scattered `-2` and `-4` calculations throughout the codebase
- Confusion about what "width" means in different contexts
- Repeated bugs when someone forgets the adjustment
- No clear terminology for the two width concepts

## Solution

Establish **outerWidth** and **innerWidth** as standard terminology with a clear relationship:

```
parent.innerWidth = child.outerWidth
```

### Terminology

| Term | Meaning |
|------|---------|
| **outerWidth** | How wide the box looks on screen (including border) |
| **innerWidth** | Room inside for content (after border + padding) |

### Visual Model

```
Overlay
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ outerWidth: 60
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ innerWidth: 54  ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê
‚îÇ                          ‚îÇ  parent.innerWidth = child.outerWidth
ComboBox                   ‚îÇ
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ outerWidth: 54  ‚Üê‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ innerWidth: 50
‚îÇ
Text content: 50 chars
```

### Design Principles

1. **Each component owns its box model** - border/padding calculations are internal implementation details
2. **Parent passes outerWidth to child** - "here's how wide you should be"
3. **Child calculates its own innerWidth** - "here's how much room I have inside"
4. **Style functions encapsulate lipgloss quirks** - caller never sees `-2`
5. **Consistent naming** - use outerWidth/innerWidth everywhere

### Implementation Pattern

**BEFORE (broken - leaks lipgloss quirk):**
```go
// Caller must know about border
inputStyle := styleComboBoxInput().Width(c.Width - 2)
```

**AFTER (encapsulated):**
```go
// Component handles its own box model
inputStyle := borderedInputStyle(c.outerWidth, c.focused)

func borderedInputStyle(outerWidth int, focused bool) lipgloss.Style {
    return lipgloss.NewStyle().
        Border(lipgloss.RoundedBorder()).
        BorderForeground(borderColor(focused)).
        Padding(0, 1).
        Width(outerWidth - 2)  // lipgloss quirk hidden here
}
```

### Files to Change

1. **combobox.go**:
   - Style functions take outerWidth parameter
   - Remove `-2` from View() call sites
   - Add innerWidth() helper for content sizing
   - Use currentThemeWrapper() for dimming support

2. **chipcombobox.go**:
   - Consistent with combobox changes

3. **chips.go**:
   - Document Width as outerWidth
   - Use currentThemeWrapper() for dimming support

4. **overlay_base.go**:
   - Rename ContentWidth() to InnerWidth() for consistency (or alias)
   - Document the outerWidth/innerWidth relationship

5. **Add constants** (in overlay_base.go or new layout.go):
   ```go
   const (
       BorderSize      = 2  // lipgloss RoundedBorder adds 2 to visual width
       InputPadding    = 2  // Padding(0, 1) = 2 horizontal
       InputBoxOverhead = 4  // BorderSize + InputPadding
   )
   ```

### Success Criteria

- [ ] No `-2` or `-4` magic numbers at call sites
- [ ] All style functions that create bordered boxes take outerWidth
- [ ] Components calculate innerWidth internally
- [ ] outerWidth/innerWidth terminology documented
- [ ] All components use currentThemeWrapper() for dimming support

title: Determine how to prioritize beads beyond course-grained priority
description:
When using beads for my personal to-do, I want to have a list of the things I'm going to do next. Kind of a linear list, just ordered list. So I need to think a bit how I should do that in beads and be able to show it in Abacus.

Jira has a good way to do that where they have a rank field and they can just drag and drop things to reprioritize them. I feel like I need something like that because I need to be able to look at the most important things to work on. And that's not dictated by any of the fields in beads today.

There is a priority field, but it's so granular that I would just have like five categories with a ton of things in each category. But I need to be able to very fluidly reprioritize my work on the fly. And a terminal UI is probably not the easiest way to do that, but I'm sure we can find a way. 

This involves two aspects here. One is how will I store the priority in a way that I can reorder that pretty dynamically for things that need to get done. And the other is how will I do that in a UI to make it user friendly? Perhaps we have different views we can use, such as a custom priority view, or priority by label, or priority by project. Maybe we can create some custom views to display these items in different ways based on what my use case is. Perhaps even having a separate list other than the tree, which is the priority to-do list. The tree shows you the structure, the priority list shows you the next few things to work on. I don't know, I need to think through this.
